title: Mantle

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of wool (camelid), plain weave; embroidered in stem stitches; corners edged with weft-faced plain weave with extended ground weft fringe and embroidered in cross-knit loop stitches.

description:
This expansive mantle, designed to be wrapped around the shoulders, features over 50 figures in brightly colored embroidery, a form of embellishment composed of needle-worked stitches. With their heads bent to the side, each figure wears a headdress, ear ornaments, and a tunic with a decorated border, and carries a feline under one arm. The pronounced stripes on the animal’s legs identify it as the pampas cat, a predator known to protect crops. Scroll-like motifs that emerge from the figures’ mouths and upraised hands may mimic the protruding tongues of the cats and signal an effort to embody the supernatural forces that govern the natural world.

The Paracas employed a number of textile embellishment techniques, and their embroidery work remains particularly impressive to modern eyes. Although all of the embroidery is done in a single stitch, the medley of colors demonstrates that the Paracas possessed a rigorous understanding of dyeing.
medium_display: Wool (camelid), plain weave; embroidered in stem stitches; corners edged with weft-faced plain weave with extended ground weft fringe and embroidered in cross-knit loop stitches
publication_history:
Christa C. Mayer-Thurman, “Recent Textile Accessions,” Calendar of the Art Institute of Chicago 66, 2 (Nov.-Dec. 1972): 6-7, fig. 1.

Anne Paul, “Paracas Necropolis Textiles: Symbolic Visions of Coastal Peru,” in The Ancient Americas: Art from Sacred Landscapes, exh. cat., Richard F. Townsend, ed. (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago, 1992), 278, color fig. 1. 

Alan R. Sawyer, Early Nasca Needlework (London: Laurence King Publishing, 1997), 111-13, color fig. 81.

Richard Townsend with Elizabeth Pope, Indian Art of the Americas at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago with Yale University Press, 2016), 270 (detail) and 285, cat 277.
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, Selected Textile Acquisitions Since 1967, July 10, 1972–Apr. 30, 1973. Art Institute of Chicago, Department of Africa, Oceania, and the Americas, May 29- Sept. 11, 1985. Art Institute of Chicago, European Textile Masterpieces from Coptic Times through the Nineteenth Century, Sept. 27, 1989–Jan. 22, 1990. Art Institute of Chicago, Department of Africa, Oceania, and the Americas, Aug. 25, 1989- Feb. 27, 1990. Art Institute of Chicago, The Ancient Americas: Art from Sacred Landscapes, Oct. 10, 1992–Jan. 3, 1993, cat. 214; travelled to Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, Feb. 4-Apr. 18, 1993, and Los Angeles County Museum of Art, June 6-Aug. 15, 1993 (Chicago only). Art Institute of Chicago, Department of African and Amerindian Art, Gallery 136, Sept. 27, 2011-Apr. 10, 2012. Art Institute of Chicago, Super/Natural: Textiles of the Andes, Feb. 23-June 16, 2019, no cat.
provenance_text: Unknown private collector, by 1933; sold Puttick & Simpson, London, October 5, 1933, lot 15 (ill.) [sales catalogue “Catalogue of a Collection of Peruvian Antiquities Comprising Superb Textiles & Pottery from Paracas, the Property of a Gentleman,” copy in curatorial object file]. John Wise, New York, by 1969 [corrspondence with J. Wise in curatorial file; Permanent receipt RX7353 dated 1/26/1970 in curatorial file]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1970.
